div1.head: Mac. to Paul Sept 21st 1916
div1.opener:
Sept 21st 1916
Am sending first sheets of eclope speil [sic] — rest tomorrow.
Dear Paul:
div1.p: E.A. Marshall hails from Long Island, N. Y. Don’t know town. Came over at early part of war. Speaking no French he was to be put in Legion but due to French parentage was allowed to serve in Active French regiment. For 19 months he was in trenches of Bois le Pretre, Due to base ball arm was made a bomber. When information was once wanted Marshall volunteered to capture a Boche. He sneaked out at night to German lines and returned leading Hun by the ear. Was awarded Croix de Guerre. Recently sent to Verdun. Negotiated a successful attack without injury save an eclat bruise and was again cited for brilliant work. As you know De Sillac informs me that the boy is slated for Aviation. He’s a good little writer. You might make a deal with him some way. Shall I ask him? Hope he gets transferred.

Letter from Eyre says he has no news from Page. Then
he adds “Do not hesitate to let me ^or Paul know all the news at the front.” Don’t you like the word hesitate?

I’m getting damned discouraged about my back. Thank God the experiments are over. Ought to be in soft here. Wrote Polly Root, and her committee is forwarding bales of stuff to this joint. Can’t get em [sic] to make my bed up, tho, [sic] and I can’t do it cause of my back. So I lie midst the bread crumbs. Grate! [sic]
Am starting on the eclope speil [sic]. Any news from Haviland.. [?]
What do you mean when you say: “How did the slider come out?”

Wrote Yvonne that I lay awake at nights thinking about her and then after that I was afraid to go to sleep. I wonder if she’ll catch on, and if so will stand for it? Thought it time to play first cards. (Have heard from her)[.]
Am freezing my balls off here. All my clothes with escadrille — even coat. Have sent for it, tho. [sic]

closer.seg: Heard from Skipper. Interesting bunch at Luxeuil.
